DT Article
TI Revision of Hista Oiticica (Lepidoptera: Castniidae) and discussion on
   the validity of its subspecies.
AU Moraes, Simeao S.
   Duarte, Marcelo
   Gonzalez, Jorge M.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2421
PS 1-27
PD 8 Apr 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2421.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/1/zt02421p027.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Diurnal Lepidoptera tend to have colorful and conspicuous wing patterns,
   which is the reason the first classifications of day-flying moths and
   butterflies were based mainly on wing color and pattern characters. This
   is the case with the Neotropical Castniidae, which are usually large and
   colorful day-flying moths. One classification listed 134 species in 32
   genera while an alternate classification recognized 81 species. In this
   paper we examine the taxonomic structure of the genus Hista Oiticica. It
   is the purpose of this paper to evaluate taxonomically useful characters
   besides wing pattern with the goal of classifying the taxa of Hista
   rather than classifying the variation of its wing pattern. In so doing,
   the results resolve the differences between the two proposed
   classifications of Hista. In addition, a lectotype is designated for
   Castnia boisduvalii Walker, 1854 (new synonym of Castnia fabricii
   Swainson, 1823) to ensure the stability of the name. Other new synonyms
   are proposed for C. fabricii (C. papagaya Westwood, 1877) and Castnia
   hegemon Kollar, 1839 (C. menetriesi Boisduval, (1875) and C. hegemon
   variegata Rothschild, 1919).
C1 Duarte, Marcelo; Museu de Zoologia da Universidade de Sao Paulo, Avenida
   Nazare 481, 04263-000, Sao Paulo, Sao Paulo, Brazil, Brazil.
RI Moraes, Simeao/C-3243-2014; Duarte, Marcelo/K-7633-2012
OI Duarte, Marcelo/0000-0002-9562-2974
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Type material; Description; Synonymy;
   Taxonomy; Land zones; Neotropical region; South America
DE Hista [Brazil /  / Distribution; systematics]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Castnioidea, Castniidae
OR Castnia boisduvalii - Walker 1854 (Castniidae): [Lectotype designated,
   P. 5]. 
   Hista - Oiticica 1955 (Castniidae): [Redescription, P. 4]. 
   Hista fabricii - (Swainson 1823) (Castniidae): [Redescription, P. 11;
   Syn nov, Castnia boisduvalii Walker 1854, p. 5; Syn nov, Castnia
   papagaya Westwood 1877, p. 6; Status, Validity of subspecies, p. 16]. 
   Hista hegemon - (Kollar 1839) (Castniidae): [Redescription, P. 20; Syn
   nov, Castnia hegemon variegata Rothschild 1919, p. 20; Syn nov, Castnia
   menetriesi Boisduval 1875, p. 19].

TI Shaoshia, an unusual new cicada genus from Pakistan with the description
   of a new species (Hemiptera: Cicadidae).
AU Wei, Cong (congwei@nwsuaf.edu.cn) 
   Ahmed, Zubair
   Rizvi, Syed Anser
SO Zootaxa
VL 2421
PS 28-34
PD 8 Apr 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2421.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/1/zt02421p034.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Shaoshia zhangi gen. & sp. n., from Pakistan, is described and placed in
   the cicada tribe Cicadatrini. The new genus is characterized by its
   completely hyaline wings with seven apical cells in the forewing and
   four apical cells in the hind wing, which is unique among Cicadidae. The
   relationship between the new genus and other taxa is discussed.

   Atlantic Forest, Brazil.

   de Souza Amorim, Dalton

AB Five new species of Coniceromyia from the Atlantic Forest in Brazil are
   herein described - Coniceromyia apechoneura, sp. nov., C. brandaoi, sp.
   nov., C. diaphaniptera, sp. nov., C. franciscana, sp. nov., and C.
   sanctaetheresae, sp. nov. Both C. diaphaniptera and C. franciscana have
   patterned wings. The male foretibia provides important diagnostic
   features for the species, as well as additional characters to propose
   clades within the genus. The male hypopygial morphology is described.

   with description of a new species of the genus Anoplophilus Karny, 1931
   from Korea.

   Paik, Jong-Cheol

U1 0

AB A new subfamily Anoplophilinae Storozhenko & Paik subfam. nov. of the
   Rhaphodophoridae is established for two genera, Anoplophilus Karny, 1931
   (type genus) and Alpinanoplophilus Ishikawa, 1993, distributed in Japan
   and Korea. Keys to the subfamilies of the Rhaphidophoridae and the
   genera of the new subfamily are provided. An annotated list of known
   genera and species of the Anoplophilinae is given. Anoplophilus koreanus
   Storozhenko & Paik sp. nov. is described from Korea.

TI Two new species of Dilaridae (Insecta: Neuroptera) with additional notes
   on Brazilian species.
AU Pires Machado, Renato Jose (rjpmachado@gmail.com) 
   Rafael, Jose Albertino

VL 2421
PS 61-68

U1 0
U2 0
AB Herein we describe two new species of lacewing in the family Dilaridae
   from northeastern Brazil: Nallachius furcatus, n. sp. and N. potiguar,
   n. sp. We also describe range expansions for three species: N. adamsi
   Penny, 1982 from Manaus to the border of the states of Amazonas and
   Para; N. dicolor Adams, 1970 from the state of Santa Catarina to the
   states of Goias and Minas Gerais; N. limai Adams, 1970 from Santa
   Catarina to Parana. An identification key to adults and a checklist of
   Brazilian species are presented.

TI Australian species of the genus Agapetus (Trichoptera: Glossosomatidae),
   with descriptions of 13 new species.
AU Wells, Alice (alice.wells@environment.gov.au) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2420
PS 1-25
PD 7 Apr 2010

AB The genus Agapetus Curtis (Trichoptera: Glossosomatidae) in Australia is
   reviewed. Among the 23 species recognised, 13 are newly described:
   Agapetus cannensis sp. nov., A. christineae sp. nov., A. dundungra sp.
   nov., A. mittamitta sp. nov., A. mossmanensis sp. nov., A. muelleri sp.
   nov., A. neboissi sp. nov., A. paluma sp. nov., A. paracralus sp. nov.,
   A. sheldoni sp. nov., A. stclairae sp. nov., A. tubrabucca sp. nov., A.
   zwicki sp. nov. Australian species occur mainly in the streams of
   Tasmania and of the Great Dividing Range on the mainland. Diagnostic
   characteristics and the known distribution for each Australian species
   are discussed briefly and a key to males of Australian species is
   provided.

DT Article
TI Two new fossil species of Itaphlebia (Mecoptera: Nannochoristidae) from
   Jiulongshan Formation, Inner Mongolia, China.
AU Liu, Nan (rendong@mail.cnu.edu.cn) 
   Zhao, Yunyun
   Ren, Dong
SO Zootaxa
VL 2420
PS 37-45
PD 7 Apr 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2420.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/1/zt02420p045.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species, Itaphlebia exquisita sp. nov and Itaphlebia laeta sp.
   nov., were collected from the Jiulongshan Formation (Middle Jurassic) of
   Daohugou, Inner Mongolia, China. A key to the species of the genus
   Itaphlebia is provided and diagnosis of the genus is revised. Itaphlebia
   exquisita sp. nov differs from other species in having an extra medial
   vein branch. Itaphlebia laeta sp. nov shows a transitional character to
   the extant genera by having a simple Sc. These new findings expand the
   distribution of Itaphlebia from middle-southern Russia to northeastern
   China.
C1 Liu, Nan; College of Life Science, Capital Normal University, Beijing
   100048, China, China.
EM rendong@mail.cnu.edu.cn

DT Article
TI The first metazoa living in permanently anoxic conditions.
AU Danovaro, Roberto (r.danovaro@univpm.it) 
   Dell'Anno, Antonio
   Pusceddu, Antonio
   Gambi, Cristina
   Heiner, Iben
   Kristensen, Reinhardt Mobjerg
SO BMC Biology
VL 8
IS 30
PS 1-10
PD 6 April 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.biomedcentral.com/content/pdf/1741-7007-8-30.pdf
AW http://www.biomedcentral.com/content/pdf/1741-7007-8-30.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Background: Several unicellular organisms (prokaryotes and protozoa) can
   live under permanently anoxic conditions. Although a few metazoans can
   survive temporarily in the absence of oxygen, it is believed that
   multi-cellular organisms cannot spend their entire life cycle without
   free oxygen. Deep seas include some of the most extreme ecosystems on
   Earth, such as the deep hypersaline anoxic basins of the Mediterranean
   Sea. These are permanently anoxic systems inhabited by a huge and partly
   unexplored microbial biodiversity. Results: During the last ten years
   three oceanographic expeditions were conducted to search for the
   presence of living fauna in the sediments of the deep anoxic hypersaline
   L'Atalante basin (Mediterranean Sea). We report here that the sediments
   of the L'Atalante basin are inhabited by three species of the animal
   phylum Loricifera (Spinoloricus nov. sp., Rugiloricus nov. sp. and
   Pliciloricus nov. sp.) new to science. Using radioactive tracers,
   biochemical analyses, quantitative X-ray microanalysis and infrared
   spectroscopy, scanning and transmission electron microscopy observations
   on ultra-sections, we provide evidence that these organisms are
   metabolically active and show specific adaptations to the extreme
   conditions of the deep basin, such as the lack of mitochondria, and a
   large number of hydrogenosome-like organelles, associated with
   endosymbiotic prokaryotes. Conclusions: This is the first evidence of a
   metazoan life cycle that is spent entirely in permanently anoxic
   sediments. Our findings allow us also to conclude that these metazoans
   live under anoxic conditions through an obligate anaerobic metabolism
   that is similar to that demonstrated so far only for unicellular
   eukaryotes. The discovery of these life forms opens new perspectives for
   the study of metazoan life in habitats lacking molecular oxygen.
C1 Danovaro, Roberto; Department of Marine Science, Faculty of Science,
   Polytechnic University of Marche, Via Brecce Blanche, 60131 Ancona,
   Italy, Italy.
EM r.danovaro@univpm.it
SC Biochemistry &Molecular Biology; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology;
   Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Marine &Freshwater Biology
SN 1741-7007
BD Biochemistry; Evolution; Habitat; Abiotic factors; Chemical factors;
   Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean; North Atlantic
DE Pliciloricus; Rugiloricus; Spinoloricus [Biochemistry / Obligate
   anaerobic metabolism / recorded] [Evolutionary adaptation /  / ] [Marine
   habitat / Deep sea habitat / ] [Chemical factors / Sulphidic environment
   / ] [Gases / Anoxia / ] [Mediterranean Sea / L'Atalante Basin / ]. 
TN Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Loricifera
OR Pliciloricus (Loricifera). 
   Rugiloricus (Loricifera). 
   Spinoloricus (Loricifera). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14610070823
OA DOAJ Gold
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14610065803
PM 20835370
DT Article
TI Defining a clade by morphological, molecular, and toxinological
   criteria: distinctive forms related to Conus praecellens A. Adams, 1854
   (Gastropoda: Conidae).
AU Biggs, Jason S.
   Watkins, Maren
   Corneli, Patrice Showers
   Olivera, Baldomero M. (olivera@biology.utah.edu) 
SO Nautilus
VL 124
IS 1
PS 1-19
PD Apr 6 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB We carried out a definition of the Coons praecellens A. Adams, 1854,
   species group using a combination of comparative morphological data,
   molecular phylogeny based on standard genetic markers, and toxinological
   markers. Prior to this work, Conus praecellens was generally postulated
   to belong to a clade of similarly high-spired, smaller species such as
   Coons pagodus Kiener, 1845, Coons memiae (Habe and Kosuge, 1970) and
   Coons arcuatus Broderip and Sowerby, 1829. The molecular phylogeny and
   toxinological data demonstrate that these earlier hypotheses are
   incorrect, and that instead, Coons praecellens is in a branch of Coons
   that includes Coons shwa (Kuroda, 1956), Coons stupella (Kuroda, 1956),
   Coons acutangulus Lamarck, 1810, and surprisingly, some species that are
   morphologically strikingly different, Coons mitratus Sowerby, 1870, and
   Coons cylindraceus Broderip and Sowerby, 1830. A more careful analysis
   of the morphologically diverse forms assigned to Coons praecellens
   suggests that from the Philippine material alone, there are at least
   three additional species new to science, Coons andremenezi, Coons
   miniexcelsus, and Coons rizali. A reevaluation of protoconch/early
   teleoconch morphology also strongly suggests that Coons excelsus Sowerby
   III, 1908, is related to these species. Together, the different data
   suggest a clade including the 10 species above that we designate the
   Turriconus (Shikama and Habe, 1968) chide; there are additional
   distinctive forms within the clade that may be separable at the species
   level. The phylogenetic definition using the multidisciplinary approach
   described herein provides a framework for comprehensively investigating
   biodiverse lineages of animals, such as the cone snails.
C1 Olivera, Baldomero M.; Univ Utah, Dept Biol, Salt Lake City, UT, USA,
   USA.
EM olivera@biology.utah.edu
SC Zoology; Biochemistry &Molecular Biology; Anatomy &Morphology; Genetics
   &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0028-1344
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Biochemistry; Skeletal and
   supporting structures; Shell; Genetics; Evolution; Variation; Marine
   zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Conus andremenezi [North Pacific / Philippines / New species] [ /
   Vietnam / ]. 
   Conus miniexcelsus [North Pacific / Japan / New species] [ / Philippines
   / ]. 
   Conus praecellens species group [Toxins and venoms / Toxins / taxonomic
   implications] [Shell morphology /  / ] [Molecular genetics /  / ]
   [Phylogeny / Phylogenetic relationships / ] [Morphological variation / 
   / ]. 
   Conus rizali [North Pacific / Philippines / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Prosobranchia, Neogastropoda, Conoidea
OR Conus andremenezi - Olivera & Biggs 2010 (Conoidea): [Sp nov,
   Philippines (marine), P. 4]. 
   Conus miniexcelsus - Olivera & Biggs 2010 (Conoidea): [Sp nov,
   Philippines (marine), P. 5]. 
   Conus praecellens species group (Conoidea). 
   Conus rizali - Olivera & Biggs 2010 (Conoidea): [Sp nov, Type locality
   not given, P. 6].

TI An anatomical note on Moellendorffia eastlakeana (Mollendorff, 1882) a
   camaenid land snail from Vietnam (Gastropoda: Pulmonata: Camaenidae).
AU Panha, Somsak (somsakp@sc.chula.ac.th) 
   Sutcharit, Chirasak
   Dang Ngoc Can
SO Nautilus
VL 124
IS 1
PS 20-24
PD Apr 6 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Newly collected specimens of Moellendorffia eastlakeana (Mollendorff,
   1882) expand the known range of this species into Vietnam. Using these
   new Vietnamese and existing museum samples we have re-described the
   species including new information on radula and genital anatomy.
   Comparison with the type material of M. callitricha (Bavay and
   Dautzenberg, 1899) from Vietnam suggested M. callitricha is a junior
   synonym of M. eastlakeana.

DT Article
TI Terrestrial gastropods from Haida Gwaii (Queen Charlotte Islands),
   British Columbia, Canada, including description of a new northern
   endemic slug (Gastropoda: Stylommatophora: Arionidae).
AU Ovaska, Kristiina (kovaska@shaw.ca) 
   Chichester, Lyle
   Sopuck, Lennart
SO Nautilus
VL 124
IS 1
PS 25-33
PD Apr 6 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Reflecting its isolation, geography, and glacial history, the Haida
   Gwaii archipelago (Queen Charlotte Islands, British Columbia) contains
   numerous endemic and disjunct taxa of various groups of organisms, but
   terrestrial gastropods have received scant attention. During surveys of
   56 sites on Graham and Moresby Islands and 11 smaller islands, including
   remote mountain top locations, we detected 18 species of native
   terrestrial gastropods, most of which also occur in southwestern British
   Columbia. An undescribed species of semi-slug was found at four sites on
   Graham Island and six sites on Moresby Island and is formally described
   (Arionidae: Staala gwaii). Morphological and anatomical analyses suggest
   that the new slug is related to small species of Hemphillia Bland and
   Binney, 1872, but the differences are substantial, warranting the
   establishment of a new genus. The new species is of particular interest
   because it appears to be a northern endemic and a relict to the
   archipelago.
C1 Ovaska, Kristiina; Biolinx Environm Res Ltd, 424 Viaduct Ave, Melbourne,
   Vic, Australia, Australia.
EM kovaska@shaw.ca
SC Zoology
SN 0028-1344

   America; Canada

   Faunal list; terrestrial taxa]. 
   Staala gwaii [British Columbia /  / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs

   gwaii, p. 28].

DT Article
TI Another new rock gecko (genus Cnemaspis Strauch 1887) from Pulau
   Langkawi, Kedah, Peninsular Malaysia.
AU Grismer, L. Lee (lgrismer@lasierra.edu) 
   Chan, Kin Onn
SO Zootaxa
VL 2419
PS 51-62
PD 6 Apr 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2419.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02419p062.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of forest dwelling Rock Gecko, Cnemaspis roticanai sp.
   nov., is described from the upper elevations of Gunung Raya, Pulau
   Langkawi, Kedah, Peninsular Malaysia. Cnemaspis roticanai is the second
   species of Cnemaspis described from Pulau Langkawi and is differentiated
   from all other Southeast Asian Cnemaspis in having a unique combination
   of color pattern and scale characteristics including keeled subtibials,
   ventrals, subcaudals, dorsal tubercles, and forearm scales; 25-27
   paravertebral tubercles; a median row of enlarged, keeled subcaudals;
   five or six precloacal, pore-bearing scales in males separated medially
   by one or two non-pore-bearing scales; 26-29 subdigital lamellae on the
   fourth toe; no dark, longitudinal gular markings or blotches; no dark
   shoulder patch enclosing a white to yellow ocellus; and having a yellow
   to white, prescapular crescent. Cnemaspis roticanai is the latest
   species in a growing list of new taxa being discovered from the Langkawi
   Archipelago.
C1 Grismer, L. Lee; Department of Biology, La Sierra University, 4500
   Riverwalk Parkway, Riverside, California, 92515-8247, USA, USA.
EM lgrismer@lasierra.edu
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Cnemaspis roticanai [Malaysia /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Sauria, Gekkonidae
OR Cnemaspis roticanai (Gekkonidae): [Sp nov, Malaysia, P. 53].

TI Synodus cresseyi Prokofiev, 2008, an unnecessary replacement for S.
   macrocephalus Cressey, 1981, and a description of a new species from the
   Western Indian Ocean (Teleostei: Synodontidae).
AU Ho, Hsuan-Ching (zoskt@gate.sinica.edu.tw) 
   Prokofiev, Artem M.
   Shao, Kwang-Tsao
SO Zootaxa
VL 2419
PS 63-68
PD 6 Apr 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2419.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/f/zt02419p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Synodus cresseyi Prokofiev, 2008 is an unnecessary replacement name for
   S. macrocephalus Cressey, 1981 according to Article 23.9.5 of the
   International Code of Zoological Nomenclature. The material used for the
   description of S. cresseyi includes two species. One of them represents
   a new species which differs from its congeners in the following
   combination of characters: anterior palatine teeth not longer than
   posterior teeth; preopercle scaled posterior to corner of mouth;
   membranous posterior flap of anterior nostril slender, with a pointed
   tip, reaching to above posterior nostril when laid back; pectoral fins
   reaching a line connecting dorsal and pelvic fin origins; pelvic process
   broad; color in alcohol without any marking, deep brown on dorsal
   surface restricted to central two-third of head and body, about two
   scale rows above lateral line, lateral and ventral surface uniformly
   silver white without blotches.
C1 Ho, Hsuan-Ching; Biodiversity Research Center, Academia Sinica, Taipei
   115, Taiwan, Taiwan.
EM zoskt@gate.sinica.edu.tw

   Indian Ocean

DT Article
TI A review of the jumping spider fauna (Araneae: Salticidae) of Chile.
AU Richardson, Barry J.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2418
PS 1-49
PD 6 Apr 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2418.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02418p049.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The salticid fauna of Chile is relatively small, consisting of 21 known
   species in eight genera. The male and female morphology of each species
   for which material was available is shown. Two new species,
   Dendryphantes villarrica n. sp. and Euophrys flordellago n.sp. are
   described. Euophrys pehuenche Galiano, 1968 is synonymised with Euophrys
   rapida C. L. Koch, 1846. As well, three little known species, Euophrys
   saitiformis Simon, 1901, Euophrys laetata Simon, 1904 and Euophrys
   rapida C. L. Koch, 1846 are redescribed from the types. The female of
   Dendryphantes fulvipes is described for the first time. Several earlier
   described species remain unidentifiable from modern material. Eighteen
   names are listed as species inquirenda as the descriptions are
   inadequate and the location of the types unknown. Keys to the genera and
   known species are provided. Remarks on the biology and distribution of
   each species are given.
C1 Richardson, Barry J.; CSIRO Entomology, GPO Box 1700, Canberra, ACT,
   Australia, Australia.
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Synonymy; Taxonomy;
   Key; Land zones; Neotropical region; South America
DE Admesturius; Dendryphantes; Euophrys [Chile /  / Key to species]. 
   Dendryphantes villarrica [Chile /  / New species]. 
   Euophrys flordellago [Brazil /  / New species] [Chile /  / ]. 
   Salticidae [Chile /  / Key to genera] [ /  / Biology; distribution;
   systematics].

   described, Female, p. 16].

PT J
AN ZOOR14605038409
DT Article
TI Revalidation and redescription of Elachistocleis cesarii
   (Miranda-Ribeiro, 1920) (Anura: Microhylidae).
AU Toledo, Luis Felipe (toledolf2@yahoo.com) 
   Loebmann, Daniel
   Haddad, Celio F.B.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2418
PS 50-60
PD 6 Apr 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2418.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02418p060.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Elachistocleis cesarii (Miranda-Ribeiro, 1920), new combination, is
   revalidated and redescribed based on preserved specimens (syntype
   series) collected in the state of Sao Paulo. Furthermore, based on
   recently collected specimens, we increase the distribution of the
   species to the states of Minas Gerais and Goias, Brazil. This species is
   found in open areas calling during the rainy season (from September to
   February for populations of the state of Sao Paulo). The advertisement
   call is described and some basic natural history data are provided. It
   distinguishes from all other species of the genus by the combination of
   the following characters: spotted belly, dominant frequency of the
   advertisement calls about 3.5 kHz, tympanum concealed, and presence of
   postcommisural glands. The advertisement call of Elachistocleis
   piauiensis, a similar species with spotted belly from the Caatinga
   Biome, was also described to compare it with the advertisement call of
   E. cesarii.
C1 Toledo, Luis Felipe; Museum de Zoologia "Prof. Adao Jose Cardoso",
   Universidade Estadual de Campinas (UNICAMP-IB), Rua Albert Einstein s/n,
   Caixa Postal 6109, CEP 13083-863, Campinas, Sao Paulo, Brazil, Brazil.
EM toledolf2@yahoo.com
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Description; Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Amphibia, Lissamphibia, Anura,
   Microhylidae
OR Elachistocleis cesarii - (Miranda-Ribeiro 1920) (Microhylidae):
   [Redescription, P. 57; Comb nov, Transferred with status upgrading from
   Engystoma ovale, p. 50]. 
   Engystoma ovale cesarii - Miranda-Ribeiro 1920 (Microhylidae): [Referred

TI New taxa of Epiphloeinae Kuwert (Cleridae) and Chaetosomatidae Crowson
   (Coleoptera: Cleroidea).
AU Opitz, Weston (opitz@kwu.edu) 
SO Insecta Mundi
VL 0123
PS 1-28
PD 2 April 2010
PY 2010
UR http://centerforsystematicentomology.org/insectamundi/0123Opitz.pdf
AW http://centerforsystematicentomology.org/insectamundi/0123Opitz.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Twenty-one new taxa of Cleridae and one of Chaetosomatidae are described
   including four new genera: Acanthocollis, Decaphloeus, Megaphloeus, and
   Stegnoclava. Twenty new species are described: five species of Amboakis
   Opitz (A. ampla, A. antegalba, A. diffusa, A. demagna, A. waodani, one
   species of Epiphloeus Spinola (E. erwini), four species of Madoniella
   Pic (M. aspera, M. darlingtoni, M. divida, M. spilota), two species of
   Plocamocera Spinola (P. clinata, P. lena), seven species of Pyticeroides
   Kuwert (P. latisentis, P. moraquesi, P. parvoporis, P. pinnacerinis, P.
   pullis, P. turbosiris, P. ustulatis), and one species of Chaetosomatidae
   (Chaetosoma colossa).

DT Article
TI A review of Lathropus Erichson (Coleoptera: Laemophloeidae) in Florida
   and the West Indies, excluding the lesser Antilles.
AU Thomas, Michael C. (thomasm@doacs.state.fl.us) 
SO Insecta Mundi
VL 0120
PS 1-22
PD 2 April 2010
PY 2010
UR http://centerforsystematicentomology.org/insectamundi/0120Thomas.pdf
AW http://centerforsystematicentomology.org/insectamundi/0120Thomas.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The species of the genus Lathropus Erichson are reviewed for Florida and
   the West Indies, excluding the Lesser Antilles. Seven species are
   recorded from this region, three of which are described as new:
   Lathropus chickcharnie Thomas, new species, Lathropus jamaicensis
   Thomas, new species, and Lathropus rhabdophloeoides Thomas, new species.
   A lectotype is designated for Lathropus vernalis Casey, and Lathropus
   striatus Casey is synonymized under Lathropus vernalis Casey, new
   synonymy. Illustrations and a key to the species of this geographgic
   region are provided.

DT Article
TI Studies in Australian Tettigoniidae: Australian agraeciine katydids, two
   new genera from northern Australia (Tettigoniidae; Conocephalinae;
   Agraeciini).
AU Rentz, D.C.F. (orthop1@tpg.com.au) 
   Su, You Ning
   Ueshima, Norihiro
   Robinson, Martyn
SO Zootaxa
VL 2417
PS 1-39
PD 2 Apr 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2417.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/1/zt02417p039.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Two new agraeciine genera and five new species are described from
   northern Australia. Both genera have species that live in mixed
   woodlands in the tropics. Armadillagraecia Rentz, Su, Ueshima, Robinson
   gen. nov. is known from two species in the Northern Territory and one
   from Queensland. Kapalgagraecia Rentz, Su, Ueshima, Robinson gen. nov.
   is known from two species, one apparently widespread in the Northern
   Territory, the other from Groote Eylandt, NT. Cytological data are
   provided for all Armadillagraecia species but not for Kapalgagraecia. A
   table is presented documenting knowledge of the known cytology of all
   Agraeciini. The calling songs of both A. mataranka and A. yerilla Rentz,
   Su, Ueshima, Robinson gen. et spp. nov. are noted and documented by
   sonograms. Known biological, ecological and distributional data are
   presented.
C1 Rentz, D.C.F.; 19 Butler Dr, Kuranda, Queensland, 4881, Australia,
   Australia.
EM orthop1@tpg.com.au

   4].

TI Review of the species of Betasyrphus Matsumura, 1917 (Diptera:
   Syrphidae) from Madagascar with description of a new species.
AU Ssymank, Axel (Ssymanka@bfn.de) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2417
PS 40-50
PD 2 Apr 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2417.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/1/zt02417p050.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The species of the genus Betasyrphus Matsumura, 1917 from Madagascar are
   reviewed. Betasyrphus keiseri sp. nov. is described from Vohipara
   (Ramonafana National Park) and compared to the type material of
   Betasyrphus serarius (Wiedemann,1830). The latter species could not be
   confirmed from the Afrotropical region and has to be deleted from the
   Afrotropical catalogue. The male genitalia of the new species are
   figured and a key to the species from Madagascar is given. The genus
   contains 12 described Aftrotropical species, excluding two taxa of
   uncertain status. Only two valid species exist in Madagascar.
C1 Ssymank, Axel; Federal Agency for Nature Conservation (BfN, I.2.2),
   Konstantinstrasse 110, 53179 Bonn, Germany, Germany.
EM Ssymanka@bfn.de

   zones; Afrotropical region; Africa

TI Description of Asiothrixus gen. nov. (Hemiptera: Aleyrodidae) and two
   new species with diagnoses and a puparial key to species.
AU Dubey, Anil Kumar (kocc2501@ntu.edu.tw) 
   Ko, Chiun-Cheng
   Martin, Jon H.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2417
PS 51-65
PD 2 Apr 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2417.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/f/zt02417p065.pdf
LA English
U1 1
U2 1
AB A new Asian genus is diagnosed, Asiothrixus, with Aleurothrixus
   antidesmae Takahashi as type species, together with Asiothrixus
   smilaceti (Takahashi) comb. nov., Asiothrixus silvestris (Corbett) comb.
   nov., Asiothrixus specialis sp. nov. and Asiothrixus unicus sp. nov.
   Lectotypes are designated for both A. antidesmae and A. smilaceti.
   Characteristics of the new genus are discussed, and puparial diagnoses
   and illustrations for the species provided, together with a puparial key
   to species.

TI Trematode Metacercariae from cranial cavity of African catfish Clarias
   gariepinus (Burchell, 1822) in Lake Tana, Ethiopia.
AU Zhokhov, A.E. (zhokhov@ibiw.yaroslavl.ru) 
   Morozova, D.A.
   Tessema, A.
SO Biologiya Vnutrennikh Vod
VL 2
PS 62-66
PD Aprel-Mai-Iyun 2010

DT Article
TI A New Species of Cuttlefish, Sepia vecchioni (Cephalopoda, Sepiidae)
   from Colachal Coast, South India.
AU Neethiselvan, N. (drneethi@yahoo.co.in) 
   Venkatamarani, V.K.
SO Journal of American Science
VL 6
IS 4
PS 12-21
PD April 1 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species of cuttlefish Sepia vecchioni sp. nov. hitherto wrongly
   treated as S. prashadi Winckworth, 1936, collected from the Colachal
   fish landing centre (8[degree]10[minute] N, 77[degree]15[minute]E ) of
   South India is described. The dorsal mantle of S. vecchioni sp. nov. has
   distinct white stripes facing upwards in contrast to transverse zebra
   type stripes with the ends facing downward in the closely related
   species, S. prashadi. Unlike S.prashadi, a well-defined sexual
   dimorphism with respect to shape and length of arm is also seen in S.
   vecchioni sp.nov. In matured males of this species, the first and fourth
   pair of arms are greatly extended and the first pair is whip like. Males
   of this species also differ from that of S.prashadi with regard to
   sucker arrangement on hectocotylized arm . Though both the species can
   be classified under Acanthosepion species complex of Rochebrune (1984)
   based on cuttle bone characteristics, Sepia vecchioni sp.nov. also
   shares the characters of the Rhombosepion species complex of Rochebrune
   (1984) by having weakly and incompletely calcified cuttlebone. The
   comparison of morphological characters, meristic characters and
   cuttlebone characteristics of S.vecchioni sp.nov. with that of other
   five closely related species of the genus Sepia of world waters are also
   discussed.[
C1 Neethiselvan, N.; Fisheries Training and Research Center, VUTRC, Tamil
   Nadu Veterinary and Animal Sciences University, Aavin campus,
   Nanjikottai Road, Thanjavur-613 006, Tamil Nadu, India, India.
EM drneethi@yahoo.co.in
SC Zoology
SN 1545-1003
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Marine zones; Indian
   Ocean
DE Sepia vecchioni [North Indian Ocean / India, Tamil Nadu / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Cephalopoda, Coleoidea, Sepiida
OR Sepia - Linnaeus 1758 (Sepiida): [Diagnostic characters of subordinate
   taxa, P. 19]. 
   Sepia vecchioni (Sepiida): [Sp nov, India, Tamil Nadu (marine), P. 13]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14703021033
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI Endoparasites of Steindachinerina [Steindachneria] brevipinna (Eigenmann
   and Eigenmann, 1889), collected in the tributaries Corvo and Guairaca of
   Paranapanema River, Parana State, Brazil.
AU Ceschini, Tiago Lopes (tiagobiology@yahoo.com.br) 
   Takemoto, Ricardo Massato
   Yamada, Fabio Hideki
   de Aquino Moreira, Luis Henrique
   Pavanelli, Gilberto Cezar
SO Acta Scientiarum Biological Sciences
VL 32
IS 2
PS 125-130
PD Apr 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Steindachnerina brevipinna is a freshwater fish from the Curimatidae
   family, and its occurrence is restricted to some South American
   countries (Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay), distributed in the
   Paraguay, lower and upper Paraguay and lower Uruguay rivers. There are
   no parasitological studies related to this fish. The present study
   records and illustrates a species of digenean, Sphincterodiplostomum
   musculosum from subfamily Diplostominae, present on the ovary and three
   species of nematodes, Cosmoxynema vianai Travassos, 1949, Travnema
   travnema Pereira, 1938, Spinoxyuris sp., of superfamily Oxyuridea,
   parasitizing the intestine of S. brevipinna collected in the tributaries
   Guairaca and Corvo of the Paranapanema River, Parana State, Brazil.

DT Article
TI Is Difflugia nebeloides (Amoebozoa: Arcellinida) Really a Difflugia?
   Re-description and New Combination.
AU Todorov, Milcho (mtodorov@zoology.bas.bg) 
   Golemansky, Vassil
   Meisterfeld, Ralf
SO Acta Zoologica Bulgarica
VL 62
IS 1
PS 13-20
PD Apr 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Sphagnum dwelling Arcellinida is the best studied group of testate
   amoebae. Nevertheless there are many rare and poorly documented species
   that are not easily identified and therefore often overlooked. Here we
   re-describe a species that initially had been described by
   GAUTHIER-LIEVRE & THOMAS (1958) as Difflugia nebeloides. Detailed light-
   and scanning electron microscopic investigations on the shell
   ultrastructure and biometric analysis of the morphometric variability of
   this species were performed. The results clearly show that the shell in
   this species is composed of a mixture of oval, circular and quadrangular
   siliceous shell plates collected or predated from other Arellinida or
   Euglyphida. It has the typical test structure of the genus Nebela. Based
   on these results, the following systematic change is proposed: Nebela
   nebeloides comb. nov. (Syn.: Difflugia nebeloides GAUTHIER-LIEVRE &
   THOMAS, 1958).
C1 Todorov, Milcho; Bulgarian Acad Sci, Inst Zool, Sofia, Bulgaria,
   Bulgaria.
EM mtodorov@zoology.bas.bg
SC Zoology
SN 0324-0770
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Description; Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position
TN Protozoans
ST Protozoa, Sarcomastigophora, Sarcodina, Rhizopoda, Lobosea,
   Testacealobosia, Arcellinida
OR Difflugia nebeloides - Gauthier-Lievre & Thomas 1958 (Arcellinida):
   [Referred to, Nebela, p. 19]. 
   Nebela nebeloides - (Gauthier-Lievre & Thomas 1958) (Arcellinida):
   [Redescription, P. 14; Comb nov, Transferred from Difflugia, p. 19]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14610067523

TI A New Spider Species Harpactea krumi sp n. from Bulgaria (Araneae,
   Dysderidae).
AU Lazarov, Stoyan (slazarov@zoology.bas.bg) 
SO Acta Zoologica Bulgarica
VL 62
IS 1
PS 27-31
PD Apr 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The new species is described and illustrated by male and female
   specimens collected in North-East Bulgaria (Kranevo and Albena). The
   male palps of the new species resemble these of Harpactea strandjica
   Dimmtov, 1997, but the embolus is more slender and curved not bifurcated
   apicaly. The conductor is lamelliform, provided with hook-form growth.

TI To the Knowledge of the Grassflies (Diptera: Chloropidae) of Greece with
   Description of Two New Species.
AU Nartshuk, Emilia P. (chlorops@zin.ru) 
SO Acta Zoologica Bulgarica
VL 62
IS 1
PS 61-70
PD Apr 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Faunistic data of Diptera species of the family Chloropidae from Greece
   including two subfamilies, 21 genera and 51 species are given, 35 of
   which are recorded for the first time in Greece. Two new species are
   described: Dicraeus beschovskii sp. n. and Oscinimorpha graeca sp. n..
   Variation in colour of scutum of Elachiptera bimaculata (LOEW) is
   discussed. Male genitalia of E. bimaculata (LOEW) and Oscinimorpha
   novakii (STROBL) are illustrated. Short analysis of ranges of included
   species is done.

DT Article
TI New host plants and geographic distribution of Melanagromyza floris
   Spencer, M. tomaterae Steyskal, M. viridis (Frost) and Ophiomyia
   lantanae (Froggatt) (Diptera: Agromyzidae) in Mexico.
FT Nuevos registros de plantas y hospederas distribucion geografica de
   Melanagromyza floris Spencer, M. Tomaterae Steyskal, M. Viridis (Frost)
   y Ophiomyia lantanae (Froggatt) (Diptera: Agromyzidae) en Mexico.
AU Palacios-Torres, Rogelio Enrique (palaciost@colpos.mx) 
   Valdez-Carrasco, Jorge Manuel
   Etienne, Jean
   Vega-Munoz, Ricardo
   Marin-Sanchez, Jose
   Castaneda-Vildozola, Alvaro
   Nava-Diaz, Cristian
SO Acta Zoologica Mexicana Nueva Serie
VL 26
IS 1
PS 59-71
PD Apr 2010
PY 2010
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 2
AB The objective of this study was to document new host plants and the
   geographical distributions of Melanagromyza floris Spencer, M. tomaterae
   Steyskal, M. viridis (Frost) and Ophiotnyia lantanae (Froggatt). The
   study was carried out from August 2007 to August 2008. Puparia of these
   flies were collected on Tithonia sp. in Tonatico (state of Mexico);
   Physalis nicandroides Schltd in Atotonilco el Grande (state of Hidalgo);
   Tagetes erecta L. and Lantana camara L. in Huautla (state of Hidalgo)
   and Lantana camara L. in San Joaquin, state of Queretaro. Both flies and
   host plants were identified. 7: erecta is a new host record for M.
   floris whereas P. nicandroides is a new host record for M. tomaterae.
   The flies M. floris and M. tomaterae are the first reports for these
   species in the state of Hidalgo. M. viridis is recorded from the
   southern part of the state of Mexico. Finally, 0. lantanae is registered
   in two states: Hidalgo and Queretaro.

   (CITRUS SINENSIS L.) DE LA CHONTALPA, TABASCO, MEXICO.

SO Acta Zoologica Mexicana Nueva Serie
VL 26
IS 1
PS 229-231
PD Apr 2010
PY 2010
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 2
AB Six parasitoid species from three families of Hymenoptera were
   identified attacking whiteflies and armored scales on orange crops in
   the Chontalpa region of Tabasco, Mexico. These were: Arrhenophagus
   chionaspidis (Auvr.), Encarsia citrina (Craw), E. haitiensis Dozier, E.
   poplexa (Huang & Polaszek), Erennocerus sp. and Signiphora sp., all of
   which are new records for the region and the state.

   Tabasco,Cuauhtemoc 908, Cardenas, Tabasco, Mexico, Mexico.

DT Article
TI THE PROTURA FROM LIUPAN MOUNTAIN, NORTHWEST CHINA.
AU Bu, Yun (ybu@sibs.ac.cn) 
   Yin, Wen-Ying
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 35
IS 2
PS 278-286
PD Apr 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The Huashanentulus huashanensis Yin, 1980 is redescribed, including the
   supplemental description of larva I, larva II and preimago stages, as
   well as helmet-like appendix on the calyx of maxillary and pores on the
   body. H. liupanensis sp. nov. is described and compared with the H.
   huashanensis. The new species is characterized by the short maxillary
   gland and extremely long sensillum a on foretarsus. The list of 15
   species of Protura from Liupan Mountain area is also provided.
C1 Bu, Yun; Chinese Acad Sci, Shanghai Inst Biol Sci, Shanghai, China,
   China.
EM ybu@sibs.ac.cn

TI NEW SPECIES AND RECORDS OF THE SUBGENUS OXYPORUS OF THE GENUS OXYPORUS
   FROM SICHUAN AND NINGXIA, CHINA (COLEOPTERA, STAPHYLINIDAE, OXYPORINAE).
AU Zheng, Fa-Ke
   Li, Yu-Jie
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 35
IS 2
PS 300-309
PD Apr 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Twelve species of the subgenus Oxyporus of the genus Oxyporus are
   reported based on specimens from Sichuan and Ningxia, China. Among them,
   four new species, O. aureomarginatus, O. beichuanus, O. hailuogou and O.
   humerosus are described and illustrated. One new subspecies, O. altus
   yanae is briefly characterized. The male sexual characters of O. Zheng
   is described for the first time. Additional distribution records of
   Oxyporus altus Huang, Zhao et Li, O. germanus Sharp, O. humerocroceus
   Huang, Zhao et Li, O. riparius Zheng, O. rufus (Linne), O. sinicus
   Huang, Zhao et Li and O. transversesulcatus Bernhauer are provided.
C1 Zheng, Fa-Ke; China W Normal Univ, Life Sci Coll, Nanchong, Sichuan,
   China, China.

TI A NEW SPECIES OF EIRENE (CNIDARIA, LEPTOMEDUSAE, EIRENIDAE) FROM XIAMEN
   HARBOUR, FUJIAN, CHINA.
AU Huang, Jia-Qi
   Xu, Zhen-Zu
   Lin, Mao (lm3011@l26.com) 
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 35
IS 2
PS 372-375
PD Apr 2010
PY 2010
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB In this paper, samples of Eirene were collected from Xiamen harbour at
   in May and Aug. 2009. Through the analysis of 34 samples, one new
   species of Eirene i. e. E. xiamenensis sp. nov. is described. All type
   species are deposited in Third Institute of Oceanography, SOA. The
   specific diagnosis of E. xiamenensis sp. nov. is as follow: umbrella
   hemispherical, jelly thick; peduncle broad at the base, the length about
   1/4 of umbrella diameter; stomach short, four long lips with folded
   margin; gonads long oval from the base Of peduncle to middle portion of
   radial canals; 24-41 tentacles with excretory papillae; 1-3 marginal
   vesicles between successive tentacles, main two.

TI A NEW SPECIES OF THE GENUS AMBLYGAMASUS AND A NEW RECORD SPECIES OF THE
   GENUS PROCTOLAELAPS FROM CHINA (ACARI, PARASITIDAE, ACEOSEJIDAE).
AU Bai, Xue-Li
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 35
IS 2
PS 387-391
PD Apr 2010
PY 2010
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB Amblygamasus gongzhengdai sp. nov. (Figs. 1-11) The new species is
   similar to Amblygamasus liujingyuani Ma, 2008, but differs from the
   latter in; 1) the body larger, length 1 035 (1 032-1 038), width 725
   (720-730), blunt front end back round, bearing 120 pairs of setae, while
   the body small, length 781 (753-806), width 563 (538-591), front than
   the back straight, bearing 60 pairs of setae; 2) the Yield within the
   device with three large teeth on both sides of the center with three
   layers of about 9-11 teeth, while that of the Yield within the device
   with two groups of shallow stab, deep with a regular arrangement of a
   number of thorns in the cavity, ossification strong; 3) male mites with
   finger-like guide fine toe, chest plate 1 on the leading edge close to
   the whole web, while there male mites with finger-like guide fine toe,
   chest plate 1 on the leading edge close to the whole web; 4) the al1
   finger to the knee section, section 2 refers to the thumb-like, while
   the al1 finger to the knee section, section 2 refers to spinulose.
   Holotype [female], paratypes; 1 [female], 1 [male], by BAI Xue-Li
   collected off Flower Market Banyan Ficus microcarpa bonsai soil surface,
   21 Sep. 2009, Yinchuan (38. 5[degree]N, 106. 3[degree] E) of Ningxia Hui
   Autonomous Region. All type specimens are deposited in the Institute of
   Microbiology and Epidemiology Academy of Military Medical Science,
   Beijing, China. Etymology. This new specie is named in honor of Dr. GONG
   Zheng-Da, a famous medical Siphonapterology in China. Proctolaelaps
   loagipilis (Chant, 1958) (Figs. 12-16) The first record in China. 6
   females were collected in 11 Aug. 2009, off the Alocasia macrorrhizos
   the soil surface in the pot, suburban flower market Yinchuan, Ningxia
   Hui Autonomous Region, from Guangzhou.
C1 Bai, Xue-Li; Ningxia Hui Autonomous Reg Ctr Dis Control & Prev, Ningxia,
   China, China.

TI A NEW SPECIES OF THE GENUS ASONUS YIN FROM QINGHAI PROVINCE (ORTHOPTERA,
   ARCYPTERIDAE).
AU Chen, Zhen-Ning
   Zheng, Zhe-Min
   Zeng, Yang
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 35
IS 2
PS 392-394
PD Apr 2010
PY 2010
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB In the present paper, a new species of Asonus Yin from Qinghai Province
   is described. Type specimens are deposited in the Institute of Zoology,
   Shaanxi Normal University and College of Life and Geographical Sciences,
   Qinghai Normal University. Asonus amplifurculus sp. nov. (Figs. 1-11)
   The new species is allied to Asonus microfurculus Yin, 1984 and Asonus
   longisulcus Yin, 1984. It differs from both in; 1) frontal ridge with
   longitudinal sulcus; 2) longitudinal diameter of eyes as long as
   subocular furrow; 3) length of elytra 2. 8 times its width; 4) furcula
   larger; 5) anal plate of male longer than its wide, with a sulcus in the
   middle of basal half of anal plate; 6) subgenital plate of male long and
   slender, reaching beyond the top of circus distinctly. It differs from
   Asonus longisulcus in the following characters: 1) frontal ridge with
   longitudinal sulcus; 2) length of longitudinal diameter of eyes as long
   as subocular furrow; 3) length of elytra 2. 8 times its width; 4) top of
   elytra sharp; 5) length of anal plate of male longer than its wide, with
   a sulcus in the middle of basal half of anal plate; 6) furcula larger;
   7) subgenital plate of male long and slender, reaching beyond the top of
   circus distinctly; 8) length of prozona 1. 6 times the length of
   metazoan. Length of body; [male] 14 mm; [female] 18-19 mm. Length of
   pronotum : [male] 3 mm; [female] 3. 5-4. 0 mm Length of elytra; [male]
   3. 2 mm; [female] 3. 2-3. 5 mm. Length of hind femur; [male] 9 mm;
   [female] 10. 0-10. 5 mm. Holotype [male], Qinghai, Guide ( 36[degree] N,
   101[degree]2[minute]E), 18 July 2008, collected by CHEN Zhen-Ning.
   Paratypes 1 [female], Qinghai, Guide, 18 July 2008, collected by ZENG
   Yang; 3 [female] [female], Qinghai, Guide, 3 Aug. 2008, collected by
   ZENG Yang and CHEN Zhen-Ning, 14 [male] [male], 21 [female] [female],
   Qinghai, Guide, 22 Aug. 2008, collected by ZENG Yang, CHEN Zhen-Ning.
   Etymology. The specific name derives from the Latin "ampl" and "furcula"
C1 Chen, Zhen-Ning; Qinghai Normal Univ, Key Lab Educ, Xining, China,
   China.

   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China

DT Article
TI A NEW SPECIES OF THE GENUS INTERPHASMA FROM CHINA (PHASMATODEA,
   PHASMATIDAE).
AU Xu, Fang-Ling
   Yang, Mao-Fa (yangmaofa68@hotmail.com) 
   Guo, Gang-Hu
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 35
IS 2
PS 395-397
PD Apr 2010
PY 2010
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Interphasma, Interphasma leigongshanense sp.
   nov. is described from Guizhou, China. The type specimens are deposited
   in the Institute of Entomology, Guizhou University. Interphasma
   leigangshanense sp. nov. (Figs. 1-4) Female. Medium sized. Body brown.
   Head and body corved with sparse granules. Head elliptical, antennae
   shorter than fore femora, 15-segmented, 1st joint depressed and wide,
   with longitudinal carina, joint cylindrical, about half as long as 1st
   one. Eyes semiglobate. Pronotum trapezoidal, transverse and longitudinal
   sulci crossing in the middle. Mesothorax and metathorax with distinctly
   dorsal longitudinal carina and sparse granules, median segment
   transverse, about 1/3 length of metanotum. Carina on legs obvious,
   without teeth or spines, fore femur length nearly equal to that of
   mesothorax and metathorax, mid femur nearly as long as mesothorax.
   Abdomen cylindrical, 2nd segment transverse, 7th segment without median
   bulge, 8th segment shrinkage, 9th sternite tergum liguliform. Operculum
   cymbiform, with apical longitudinal carina, not surpassing abdominal
   apex. Cerci coniform, surpassing apex of abdomen. Male. Medium sized,
   brown, smooth, thinner than female. Head elliptical, antennae shorter
   than fore femora, 17-segmented, 1st joint depressed and wide, 2nd joint
   depressed and short, about 1/3 length of 1st. Eyes semiglobose, more
   prominent than female. Mesothorax and metathorax with lateral carina,
   median segment transverse, about 1/4 length of metanotum. Abdomen
   cylindrical, 2nd segment length longer than wide, final 3 segments
   slightly dilated, tectiform and split into 2 lobes, base broader, curved
   inward. Subgenital plate cucullated with dorsal median ridge, extending
   the base of anal segment; cerci flat, curved inward, slightly visible.
   Measurements ( mm). Body; [female]60, [male] 47; mesonotum; [female]13,
   [male] 11; metanotun ( with median segment) : [female]8, [male] 8;
   median segment: [female]2. 5, [male] 1. 8; fore femur; [female]22. 0,
   [male] 22. 8; mid femur: [female]14, [male] 15; hind femur: [female]18,
   [male] 19. Holotype[female], paratype 1 [male], Leigongshan, Guizhou
   Province, 14 Sep. 2005, coll. XU Fang-Ling. Etymology. The species is
   named after the type locality. This new specie is similar to Interphasma
   emeiense Chen et He, but differs from the laterin the 7th sternite
   without median bulge, and the 9th sternite tergite linguiform.
C1 Yang, Mao-Fa; Guizhou Univ, Inst Entomol, Guiyang, China, China.
EM yangmaofa68@hotmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1000-0739
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Interphasma leigongshanense [Guizhou /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Orthoptera, Phasmida
OR Interphasma leigongshanense (Phasmida): [Sp nov, Guizhou, P. 396].

DT Article
TI THE GENUS ARTHULA CAMERON (HYMENOPTERA, ICHNEUMONIDAE) IN CHINA WITH
   DESCRIPTION OF A NEW SPECIES.
AU Sheng, Mao-Ling
   Sun, Shu-Ping
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 35
IS 2
PS 398-400
PD Apr 2010
PY 2010
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the family Ichneumonidae, Arthula maculifacialis sp.
   nov. collected from Jiangxi Province, China is reported. A key to
   species known in China is provided. Specimens are deposited in the
   General Station of Forest Pest management, State Forestry
   Administration, Shenyang, China. Arthula maculifacialis sp. nov. (Figs.
   1-3) The new species is similar to A. brunneocornis Cameron, 1900, but
   can be distinguished from it by antenna reddish brown, having 23
   flagellomeres; face black with large yellow fleck centrally; basal area
   of propodeum strongly convex; mesosternum entirely black; nervellus
   intercepted at its middle. A. brunneocornis Cameron: antenna darkish
   brown, its dorsal side more darker than ventral side, having 28
   flagellomeres; face entirely yellow; basal area of propodeum not or
   weakly convex; mesosternum with yellow flecks; nervellus intercepted at
   lower 0. 3. Holotype [female], Quan ' nan ( 24. 7[degree] N, 114.
   5[degree] E; alt. 340 m), Jiangxi Province, 13 May 2009, LI Shi-Chang.
   Etymology. The name of the new species is based on the face with yellow
   mark.
C1 Sheng, Mao-Ling; State Forestry Adm, Gen Stn Forest Pest Management,
   Shenyang, China, China.
SC Zoology
SN 1000-0739
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Arthula [China /  / Key to species]. 
   Arthula maculifacialis [Jiangxi /  / New species].

ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Terebrantia,
   Ichneumonoidea, Ichneumonidae
OR Arthula - Cameron 1900 (Ichneumonidae): [Key to species, China, P. 399].

DT Article
TI THE GENUS ROTHNEYIA CAMERON (HYMENOPTERA, ICHNEUMONIDAE) IN CHINA WITH
   DESCRIPTION OF ONE NEW SPECIES.
AU Sun, Shu-Ping
   Sheng, Mao-Ling
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 35
IS 2
PS 401-403
PD Apr 2010
PY 2010
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of family Ichneumonidae, Rothneyia jiangxiensis sp. nov.,
   collected from Jiangxi Province, is reported. The main characters for
   separating the new species from the similar species in the genus are
   indicated. A key to species known in China is provided. Specimen is
   deposited in the General Station of Forest Pest Management, State
   Forestry Administration, Shenyang, China. Rothneyia jiangxiensis sp.
   nov. (Figs. 1-5) The new species is similar to R. sinica He, 1995, but
   can be distinguished from the latter in having the areolet receiving
   second recurrent vein slightly basad of its middle; lower anterior
   portion of mesopleuron with transverse wrinkles, the rest portion with
   fine punctures; coxae and trochanters yellowish brown; dorsal sides of
   flagellomeres 4 to 8 white. Holotype [female] Quannan, Jiangxi Province,
   700 m, 2 July 2008, LI Shi-Chang. Etymology. The name of the new species
   is based on type locality.
C1 Sun, Shu-Ping; State Forestry Adm, Gen Stn Forest Pest Management,
   Shenyang, China, China.

TI A NEW SPECIES OF THE GENUS SPILOGONA FROM INNER MONGOLIA, CHINA
   (DIPTERA, MUSCIDAE).
AU Feng, Yan
   Wang, Yan-Xia
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 35
IS 2
PS 404-406
PD Apr 2010
PY 2010
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB The present paper describes a new species of the genus Spilogona Schnabl
   from Inner Mongolia, China i. e. Spilogona psittorhamphos sp. nov. The
   type specimens are deposited in the Medical Entomological Collection,
   Institute of Microbiology and Epidemiology AMMS, Beijing, China.
   Spilogona psittorhamphos sp. nov. (Figs. 1-4) Male. The new species
   resembles Spilogona impar ( Stein, 1907) from Qinghai Province, China,
   but can be distinguished from the latter by the following characters :
   the parafacialia about 0. 7 time as wide as 3rd antennal segment;
   steropleura setae 1 + 1; mid tibia with 1 ad; lateral lobes of 5th
   sternite as long as its basal part; cerci forward-curved on distal part
   distinctly in lateral view. Female. Body and wings length 8. 0 mm
   respectively. Width of frons on middle part about 0. 5 time as wide as
   its head; interfrontalia slightly constricted in inward on distal part,
   without interfrontal seta; inner margin of parafrontalia with 4
   infraorbital setae in inward and 2 setae in upward, frontal triangle
   reaching the premargin of frons. Abdomen ground colour as steel-blues,
   covered with thinner fulvous pruinescence. Mid tibia with 1 av and 1 pu
   seta in juxtaposed on part distal 1/3, middle part with 2 ad and 2 p
   setae; hind tibia with 4 ay and 2 ad setae on middle part, 1 pd on
   premedial part; other characters same as this male. Holotype [male],
   Ulanhe (36. 9[degree]N, 98. 4[degree]E; alt. 700 m), Inner Mongolia,
   China, 24 June 1978, collector YE Zong-Mao. Paratypes 1 [male], 1
   [female], same as holotype. Etymology. The specific name is derived from
   the Greek word " psitt " combined with " rhamphos ", referring that of
   the cerci and surstyli as parrotal beak in lateral view.

TI A NEW SPECIES OF THE GENUS PSEUDOHYNOBIUS (CAUDATA, HYNOBIIDAE) FROM
   GUIZHOU, CHINA.
AU Li, Song
   Tian, Ying-Zhou (t.y.zhou@163.com) 
   Gu, Xiao-Ming
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 35
IS 2
PS 407-412
PD Apr 2010
PY 2010
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 1
AB The current paper deals with a new species of Pseudohynobius collected
   in Yanxia Twon, Guiding County, Guizhou Province. Type material is
   deposited in the Department of Biology, Liupanshui Normal College.
   Pseudohynobius guizhouensis sp. nov. (Figs. 1-6) Pseudohynobius
   guizhouensis sp. nov. is similar to that of P. kuankuoshuiensis, but
   differs in several ways. The new species has dispersed white spots at
   the ventral side of their bodies and 17 trunk vertebrae; two frontal
   bones are usually connected at their anterior ends and form a triangle;
   the bounded cleft on the gap between the frontal and parietal bones is
   small to non-existence; the bifurcation of the "y" cartilage of the
   pelvic girdle is narrower and longer than that of P. kuankuoshuiensis
   (Fig. 4). On the other hand, P. kuankuoshuiensis does not have white
   spots at the ventral side and has 18 trunk vertebrae; their two frontal
   bones form an arc; the deft is distinct. Holotype male ( No. 0711005),
   adult, collected by LI Song and TIAN Ying-Zhou, 8 Mar. 2008, Yanxia
   Twon, Guiding County, Guizhou Province (26[degree]12'N, 107[degree]30'E;
   alt. 1 650 m). Paratypes; 1 female (No. 0711005), adult, collection data
   same as holotype; 2 males ( Nos. 0711001, 0711006), 2 females (Nos.
   0711002, 0711003) and 30 immature, collected by LI Song and TIAN
   Ying-Zhou, Nov. 2007 and Mar. 2008 at the same locality. The new species
   is also similar to P. flavomaculatus. The new species has round spots
   mostly on the back of their bodies and tails, and the ratio of head
   length to width is larger than 1. 54, while the latter has cloud stripe
   color spots on the upper surfaces of the body and tail and the ratio of
   head length to width is smaller than 1. 54. The new species can also be
   distinguished from P. shuichengensis by having short limbs; When
   forelimbs and hindlimbs are pressed against the body, the front parts of
   metacarpus and metatarsus are not overlapped. Furthermore, the new
   species has a lots of color spots on the back of body and tail, while P.
   shuichengensis has no color spots on its back of the body and tail.

   China.

TI A NEW SPECIES OF RHACOPHORIDAE FROM YUNNAN, CHINA (AMPHIBIA, ANURA).
AU Fei, Liang
   Ye, Chang-Yuan
   Jiang, Jian-Ping (jiangjp@cib.ac.cn) 
SO Acta Zootaxonomica Sinica
VL 35
IS 2
PS 413-417
PD Apr 2010
PY 2010
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 2
AB Feihyla fuhua sp. nov. (Figs. 1-6) Holotype male, adult, CIB584168, SVL
   27. 2 mm, Qianjinxiang, Pingbian County ( 22. 58[degree]N, 103.
   41[degree]E; alt. 1040 m), Yunnan Province, China; 16 Aug. 1958,
   collected by YANG Fu-Hua. Paratypes 5 males ( CIB584166-584167,
   584169-584171), collected with the holotype in the same place and time,
   by YANG Fu-Hua et al. Diagnosis. The new tree-frog Feihyla fuhua from
   Pingbian, Yunnan differs from Philautus palpebralis Smith, 1924 in
   having: 1) snout largely longer than diameter of eye; 2) tympanum large,
   closing to rear corner of eye; 3) fingers not webbed; toes 1/3 webbed,
   reaching distal subarticular tubercle of fifth toe; 4) inner metatarsal
   tubercle 1/2 length of fifth toe; 5) dorsum of body grayish yellow or
   yellowish, with a pair brown red arc patterns; 6) a long and wide white
   streak from below eye to the base of shoulder; 7) no green spot on
   occiput in life; 8) dark bars on limbs. In the latter having; 1) snout
   shorter, a little longer than diameter of eye; 2) tympanum small, far
   apart from rear corner of eye ( its distance from eye equal to its own
   diameter); 3) a rudiment of web between the outer two fingers; toes half
   webbed, reaching disc of fifth toe; 4) inner metatarsal tubercle 1/3
   length of fifth toe; 5) dorsum of body reddish brown, without the " "
   mark; 6) a short and narrow streak from below eye to shoulder; 7) a
   green spot on occiput in life; 8) no dark bars on limbs. The type
   specimens are preserved in Chengdu Institute of Biology, the Chinese
   Academy of Sciences.

DT Article
TI A new puddle frog (Phrynobatrachidae: Phrynobatrachus) from the Mambilla
   Plateau in eastern Nigeria.
AU Blackburn, David C. (david.c.blackburn@gmail.com) 
SO African Journal of Herpetology
VL 59
IS 1
PS 33-52
PD April 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new species of puddle frog (Phrynobatrachus) is described from the
   Kurmin Danko Forest Reserve on the western edge of the Mambilla Plateau
   in eastern Nigeria. The new species is distinguished from both
   geographically proximate and closely related Phrynobatrachus species by
   the combination of its body size (larger than the closely related P.
   chukuchuku, P. manengoubensis, and P. werneri), degree of development of
   male traits, and a unique ventral colour pattern in males. Molecular
   phylogenetic analysis reveals that this new species is closely related
   to P. werneri and P. manengoubensis, which, together with several other
   species, form a clade restricted to the mountains of the Cameroon
   Volcanic Line. This new Phrynobatrachus is the first known amphibian
   species hypothesized to be endemic to the Mambilla Plateau of eastern
   Nigeria.
C1 Blackburn, David C.; Univ Kansas, Nat Hist Museum, Lawrence, KS, USA,
   USA.
EM david.c.blackburn@gmail.com
RI Blackburn, David C./L-3812-2019
OI Blackburn, David C./0000-0002-1810-9886

   Africa
DE Phrynobatrachus danko [Nigeria /  / New species]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Amphibia, Lissamphibia, Anura, Ranidae
OR Phrynobatrachus danko (Ranidae): [Sp nov, Nigeria, P. 39].

DT Article
TI Gastrointestinal Parasites of the Chimpanzee Population Introduced onto
   Rubondo Island National Park, Tanzania.
AU Petrzelkova, Klara J.
   Hasegawa, Hideo
   Appleton, Chris C.
   Huffman, Michael A. (Huffman@pri.kyoto-u.ac.jp) 
   Archer, Colleen E.
   Moscovice, Liza R.
   Mapua, Mwanahamissi Issa
   Singh, Jatinder
   Kaur, Taranjit
SO American Journal of Primatology
VL 72
IS 4
PS 307-316
PD Apr 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 2
U2 21
AB The release of any species into a novel environment can evoke
   transmission of parasites that do not normally parasitize the host as
   well as potentially introducing new parasites into the environment.
   Species introductions potentially incur such risks, yet little is
   currently known about the parasite fauna of introduced primate species
   over the long term. We describe the results of long-term monitoring of
   the intestinal parasite fauna of an unprovisioned, reproducing
   population of chimpanzees introduced 40 years earlier (1966-1969) onto
   Rubondo Island in Lake Victoria, Tanzania, a non-native habitat for
   chimpanzees. Two parasitological surveys (March 1997 October 1998 and
   October 2002 December 2005) identified Entamoeba spp. including E. coli,
   Iodamoeba buetschlii, Troglodytella abrassarti, Chilomastix mesnili,
   Trichuris sp., Anatrichosoma sp., Strongyloides spp., Strongylida fam.
   gen. sp., Enterobius anthropopitheci, Subulura sp., Ascarididae gen.
   sp., and Protospirura muricola. The parasite fauna of the Rubondo
   chimpanzees is similar to wild chimpanzees living in their natural
   habitats, but Rubondo chimpanzees have a lower prevalence of strongylids
   (9%, 3.8%) and a higher prevalence of E. anthropopitheci (8.6%, 17.9%)
   than reported elsewhere. Species prevalence was similar between our two
   surveys, with the exception of Strongyloides spp. being higher in the
   first survey. None of these species are considered to pose a serious
   health risk to chimpanzees, but continued monitoring of the population
   and surveys of the parasitic fauna of the two coinhabitant primate
   species and other animals, natural reservoir hosts of some of the same
   parasites, is important to better understand the dynamics of host
   parasite ecology and potential long-term implications for chimpanzees
   introduced into a new habitat. Am. J. Primatol. 72:307-316, 2010. (C)
   2009 Wiley-Liss, Inc.
C1 Huffman, Michael A.; Kyoto Univ, Primate Res Inst, 41 Kanrin, Aichi,
   Japan, Japan.
EM Huffman@pri.kyoto-u.ac.jp
RI ASCR, IVB/A-9883-2011; Petrzelkova, Klara Judita/G-7111-2014
OI Huffman, Michael A/0000-0002-6166-7795
SC Zoology; Parasitology
SN 0275-2565; 1098-2345
BD Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts;
   Land zones; Afrotropical region; Africa
DE Nematoda; Protozoa [Mammalian hosts / Pan troglodytes / Prevalence;
   gastrointestinal parasites monitoring; host population introduced onto
   lake island] [Tanzania / Lake Victoria, Rubondo Island / ]. 
   Pan troglodytes [Nematode parasites /  / Prevalence; gastrointestinal
   parasites monitoring; host population introduced onto lake island]
   [Protozoan parasites /  / ] [Tanzania / Lake Victoria, Rubondo Island /
   ]. 
TN Chordates; Invertebrates; Mammals; Nematodes; Primates; Protozoans;
   Vertebrates

   Pan troglodytes (Pongidae): [Host].

DT Article
TI POLYPHYLY OF CAMPYLORHAMPHUS, AND DESCRIPTION OF A NEW GENUS FOR C.
   PUCHERANI (DENDROCOLAPTINAE).
AU Claramunt, Santiago (sclara1@tigers.lsu.edu) 
   Derryberry, Elizabeth P.
   Chesser, R. Terry
   Aleixo, Alexandre
   Brumfield, Robb T.
SO Auk
VL 127
IS 2
PS 430-439
PD Apr 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB We investigated the phylogenetic relationships of Campylorhamphus
   pucherani using DNA sequences from three mitochondrial genes and a
   nuclear intron, as well as 84 morphological characters from the
   skeleton, the integument, and the musculature. The molecular phylogeny
   indicated that C. pucherani is not part of Campylorhamphus; instead, it
   is the sister species to Drymornis bridgesii, in a clade that also
   contains Lepidocolaptes. The morphological phylogeny also placed C.
   pucherani in a clade that contains Drymornis and Lepidocolaptes. Using a
   morphometric analysis of size and shape diversity, we demonstrated that
   the inclusion of C. pucherani in Drymornis would create an excessively
   heterogeneous genus compared with other dendrocolaptine genera. Because
   no generic name is available for C. pucherani, we describe the new genus
   Drymotoxeres for this species. Received 18 June 2009, accepted 12
   October 2009.
C1 Claramunt, Santiago; Louisiana State Univ, Museum Nat Sci, Baton Rouge,
   LA, USA, USA.
EM sclara1@tigers.lsu.edu

   Aleixo, Alexandre/L-3135-2013; Claramunt, Santiago/H-5483-2019
OI Brumfield, Robb T/0000-0003-2307-0688; Aleixo,
   Alexandre/0000-0002-7816-9725; Claramunt, Santiago/0000-0002-8926-5974

TI A new species of the genus Phygasia (Coleoptera: Chrysomelidae:
   Alticinae) from Taiwan of China.
AU Ge, Deyan (gedy@ioz.ac.cn) 
   Wang, Shuyong
   Yang, Xingke
SO Biologia (Bratislava)
VL 65
IS 2
PS 325-329
PD Apr 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Continuing study on the Chinese species of Phygasia Chevrolat, 1836
   revealed 10 specimens collected from Taiwan that were distinctly
   different from other described species within this genus. The new
   species is similar to P. ornata Baly, 1876 and P. pseudornata Wang et
   Yang, 2008, but can be distinguished from them by the color and position
   of elytra markings as well as the shape of male genitalia: the black
   markings on the elytra only covered the humeral area and the sub-apical
   area of elytra, and genitalia of male pointed and short with big basal
   opening. A new species, Phygasia taiwanensis sp. n., is described
   herein.

DT Article
TI Morphology of the Muscle Articulation Joint Between the Hooks of a
   Flatworm (Kalyptorhynchia, Cheliplana sp.).
AU Uyeno, Theodore A. (Ted.Uyeno@nau.edu) 
   Kier, William M.
SO Biological Bulletin (Woods Hole)
VL 218
IS 2
PS 169-180
PD Apr 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Schizorhynch kalyptorhynchs are meiofaunal turbellarian predators that
   possess an eversible proboscis that can be armed with two stout hooks.
   The hooks grasp and manipulate prey using a wide range of rotations and
   translations. These diverse motions are possible because the hook
   supports may function as a muscle articulation type joint that is, a
   joint formed of muscle and connective tissue that connects, separates,
   and moves the microscopic hooks. We analyze the morphology of the
   flexible joint in a species of Cheliplana by using three types of
   microscopy: light, laser scanning confocal, and transmission electron.
   Radial myofilament bundles are present in the core of the hook supports,
   and lateral divaricator muscle fibers are located on their lateral
   surfaces. We develop a novel model for movements of the proboscis and
   describe the tensile function of the basement membrane that surrounds
   each hook support's medial glandular region. Contraction of divaricator
   muscle fibers antagonized by contraction of radial myofilaments causes
   the lateral bending of the hook supports and opening of the hook
   apparatus. Relaxation of the divaricator fibers and maximal contraction
   of the radial myofilaments, which put the medial basement membranes in
   tension, may cause medial bending in the hook supports and closing of
   the hook apparatus. During proboscis retraction, closure may also be
   aided by the compression of the hook apparatus as the proboscis is drawn
   through the rostral pore. The study provides new insights into the
   principles of support and movement in muscle articulations.
C1 Uyeno, Theodore A.; No Arizona Univ, Dept Biol Sci, POB 5640, Flagstaff,
   AZ, USA, USA.
EM Ted.Uyeno@nau.edu
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Nutrition &Dietetics
SN 0006-3185
BD Musculature; Nutrition; Feeding behaviour; Digestive system; Buccal
   region
DE Cheliplana [Musculature / Muscle articulation joints morphology / ]
   [Food handling / Prey handling / ] [Proboscis / Proboscis hooks / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Platyhelminths
ST Animalia, Platyhelminthes, Turbellaria
OR Cheliplana (Turbellaria). 
DI 10.1086/BBLv218n2p169
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14610067086
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR14606042766
DT Article
TI Stasis and turnover in small shearwaters on Bermuda over the last 400
   000 years (Aves: Procellariidae: Puffinus lherminieri group).
AU Olson, Storrs L. (olsons@si.edu) 
SO Biological Journal of the Linnean Society
VL 99
IS 4
PS 699-707
PD Apr 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB The extinct species Puffinus parvus Shufeldt of Bermuda is shown to be
   synonymous with the living taxon Puffinus boydi of the Cape Verde
   islands. This species occurred on Bermuda throughout the last 400 000
   years, during both glacial and interglacial intervals, and into the
   Holocene up until the arrival of humans when introduced predators
   evidently caused its extirpation. Subsequently, the island was colonized
   briefly by the Caribbean species Puffinus lherminieri, which in turn was
   extirpated from the island in the 20th Century. The indications are that
   P. boydi successfully outcompeted P. lherminieri on Bermuda until it was
   removed through human agency, thus closely paralleling the situation
   documented for two species of Megadyptes penguins in New Zealand. Thus
   P. lherminieri and P. boydi have long functioned as biological species
   and should be considered as full species along with the cold-water
   species Puffinus baroli of the North Atlantic. Restoration efforts for
   small shearwaters on Bermuda should now focus on P. boydi rather than P.
   lherminieri. (C) 2010 The Linnean Society of London, Biological Journal
   of the Linnean Society, 2010, 99, 699-707.
C1 Olson, Storrs L.; Smithsonian Inst, Natl Museum Nat Hist, POB 37012,
   Washington, DC, USA, USA.
EM olsons@si.edu
SC Zoology; Biodiversity &Conservation; Environmental Sciences &Ecology;
   Paleontology; Evolutionary Biology

PT J

DT Article
TI Uncovering an overlooked radiation: molecular phylogeny and biogeography
   of Madagascar's endemic river snails (Caenogastropoda: Pachychilidae:
   Madagasikara gen. nov.).
AU Koehler, Frank (frank.koehler@austmus.gov.au) 
   Glaubrecht, Matthias
SO Biological Journal of the Linnean Society
VL 99
IS 4
PS 867-894
PD Apr 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 12
AB By analysing key morphological characters (with emphasis on shell,
   radula and stomach anatomy) and a partial fragment of the mitochondrial
   16S rRNA gene (alignment length 860 bp), we examined patterns of
   diversity and differentiation of a previously overlooked radiation of
   Madagascan pachychilid freshwater gastropods. These analyses resulted in
   the discovery of three new species in addition to the two species that
   were already recognized. The complex nomenclatural and taxonomic
   implications are discussed and the finding of a viviparous reproductive
   mode in at least one among otherwise oviparous species is reported.
   Using a mitochondrial phylogeny that includes all currently accepted
   pachychilid genera and a strict molecular clock approach, we address the
   historical biogeography of the Madagascan species with respect to
   vicariant versus dispersalist biogeographical models. Using two
   alternative calibrations that were previously suggested for other
   gastropods, the molecular clock tree suggested that the origin of the
   Pachychilidae dates back to no more than 50 Mya, whereas the origin of
   the Madagascan lineage is estimated to date to a period between
   15.6-31.5 Mya. These estimates are approximately concurrent with the
   dating of colonization events in a number of other Madagascan animal
   taxa. The pachychilid radiation on Madagascar appears not to be older
   than 3-5 Mya. Thus, although the global patterns of pachychilid
   distribution have earlier been interpreted to suggest a Gondwanan origin
   of the family, the present study does not support this postulate.
   Neither the topology of the molecular phylogeny, nor the timing of
   events as suggested from a molecular clock were found to be congruent
   with a vicariance scenario within the framework of Gondwanan
   fragmentation during the Mesozoic but, instead, imply overseas dispersal
   during the Cenozoic. (C) 2010 The Linnean Society of London, Biological
   Journal of the Linnean Society, 2010, 99, 867-894.
C1 Koehler, Frank; Australian Museum, 6 Coll St, Sydney, NSW, Australia,
   Australia.
EM frank.koehler@austmus.gov.au
RI Kohler, Frank/C-4853-2009
OI Kohler, Frank/0000-0001-7150-6509

   genus Madagasikara, p. 873].

DT Article
TI Description of Callopanchax sidibei (Nothobranchiidae: Epiplateinae), a
   new species of killifish from southwestern Guinea, West Africa.
AU Sonnenberg, Rainer (r.sonnenberg.zfmk@uni-bonn.de) 
   Busch, Eckhard
SO Bonn Zoological Bulletin
VL 57
IS 1
PS 3-14
PD April 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species of the annual killifish genus Callopanchax
   (Nothobranchiidae: Epiplateinae) is described from coastal Guinea, West
   Africa. It is distinguished from its congeners by morphological and
   colour pattern characters including up to three irregular and
   interrupted horizontal stripes on blue flanks in males. A preliminary
   DNA study indicates that it is closely related with C. occidentalis and
   C. toddi, which is supported by the following apomorphic characters
   compared to the more distantly related C. monroviae: a dark red or black
   postopercular blotch and an origin of the dorsal fin anterior to or
   above the first ray of the anal fin. The species first turned up in
   commercial imports of ornamental fish from Guinea. The local collectors,
   the Sidibe family, are acknowledged for sharing their knowledge on this
   species and their support to the second author during his collections by
   naming it Callopanchax sidibei, new species. Currently it is only known
   from the type locality and is endemic to Guinea.
C1 Sonnenberg, Rainer; Zoologisches Forschungsmuseum Koenig, Adenauerallee
   160, D-53223 Bonn, Germany, Germany.
EM r.sonnenberg.zfmk@uni-bonn.de

BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Afrotropical
   region; Africa
DE Callopanchax sidibei [Guinea /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Cyprinodontiformes, Aplocheilidae
OR Callopanchax monroviae - (Roloff & Ladiges 1972) (Aplocheilidae):
   [Diagnostic characters, P. 7]. 
   Callopanchax occidentalis - (Clausen 1966) (Aplocheilidae): [Diagnostic
   characters, P. 7].

AN ZOOR14610072386
DT Article
TI A new chameleon of the Trioceros bitaeniatus complex from Mt. Hanang,
   Tanzania, East Africa (Squamata: Chamaeleonidae).
AU Krause, Patrick (paddy.krause@web.de) 
   Boehme, Wolfgang
SO Bonn Zoological Bulletin
VL 57
IS 1
PS 19-29
PD April 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A new species of Trioceros from the montane forests of Mount Hanang in
   Northwest Tanzania is described. The only known population of this
   species is found on Mt. Hanang in Tanzania around 2800 m a.s.l. This
   chameleon bears close morphological resemblance to Trioceros sternfeldi
   (Rand, 1963) from northern Tanzania. In order to infer phylogenetic
   relationships within the group, morphological and genetic data
   (mitochondrial 16S and 12S rRNA genes) were analysed. The new species
   could be compared with specimens of different populations of Trioceros
   sternfeldi (Mts. Meru, Kilimanjaro and Ngorongoro) and several other
   representatives of the family (T. hoehnelii, T. ellioti, T. rudis rudis,
   T. bitaeniatus). Results of maximum parsimony, maximum likelihood and
   Bayesian analyses consistently placed Trioceros n. sp. from Mt. Hanang
   as a single, independent terminal clade with high genetic divergences
   towards all other included members of the group.
C1 Krause, Patrick; Zoologisches Forschungsmuseum Alexander Koenig,
   Adenaueralle 160, D-53113 Bonn, Germany, Germany.
EM paddy.krause@web.de

   Land zones; Afrotropical region; Africa

   sequence-based phylogeny / Taxonomic implications] [Phylogeny /  / ]
   [Africa /  / ]. 
   Trioceros hanangensis [Tanzania /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates

DT Article
TI Reptiles from southern Benin, West Africa, with the description of a new
   Hemidactylus (Gekkonidae), and a country-wide checklist.
AU Ullenbruch, Klaus (Klaus-Ullenbruch@t-online.de) 
   Grell, Olaf
   Boehme, Wolfgang
SO Bonn Zoological Bulletin
VL 57
IS 1
PS 31-54
PD April 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB We report on a collection of reptiles made in southern Benin, mostly in
   the vicinity of Lama Forest, a relict rain forest surrounded by savannah
   habitats within the the so-called Dahomey gap. 48 species (3 chelonian,
   20 saurian and 25 ophidian species were encountered) are listed with the
   respective voucher material and commented in respect to taxonomic or
   ecological information. Five lizard species (Agama sylvanus,
   Hemidactylus ansorgei, H. lamaensis n. sp., Holaspis guentheri, Varanus
   ornatus) and two snake species (Natriciteres variegata, Amblyodipsas
   unicolur) are new for the fauna of Benin, the second Hemidactylus
   species being even new to science. Some other species are reported from
   Benin for only the second time. This commented list of species collected
   from southern Benin is followed by a general country-wide checklist,
   which is based on literature data and also some unpublished records from
   northern Benin, among them the remarkable rediscovery of Agama
   gracilimembris, 9 decades after its original description from this
   country.
C1 Ullenbruch, Klaus; Zoologisches Forschungsmuseum Alexander Koenig,
